nodes.bodyText: Thanks for the feedback, @gitgabrio

Presumably, given the current implementation, the channel would be empty when IsKogito is true. However I'm proposing IsKogito is killed-off and channel always returns a value... but let's wait for @jesuino to advise.

What I was testing yesterday was something  like:
If you are running Kogito and in a channel, so: isKogito==true and channel==channel where the editor is running
If you are running on Business Central or in a webapp: isKogito==false
When you test the editor in the browser (without any channel), channel.isEmpty() == true
Now adding BUSINESS-CENTRAL channel we simply would have an additional channel for Business Central only or channel.isEmpty ==true if no channel. This is what I am working right now.

As long as we only have one place to check the environment in which an editor is running I'm happy... i.e. kill off IsKogito everywhere. My preference is to simply use EditorContextProvider.getChannel() to determine where the editor is running, be it VSCode, GitHub, Business Central or elsewhere.

@jesuino @manstis
I think your comments may be merged in one solution (correct me if I'm wrong):

always return the channel identifier in one single place
do not rely on IsKogito (as you see, using it lead to a matrix of cases)

I personally agree, but still not really like the overall idea that somehow the content (i.e. the editor) should know about the container to work correctly - it seems against the concept of modularity - I have the impression there is some architectural issue behind that this "channel" information is meant to solve.
Beside that, Optional.empty() is a nice way to say null, and null has not any semantical meaning: I would prefer to always return a value or throw an exception.

My understanding is that channel may be used to determine where to show docks and which may be open by default etc based upon the container/channel... we could achieve this by composing different plugins/extensions for different containers/channels but IMO that could all too easily explode into a maintenance nightmare! There may be other uses of which I am unaware..

@manstis
If I follow correctly, that would lead to the following scenario:

editors must invoke the "channel" to know where they are running
based on that, the editor itself must implement a sort of "if" - based on the channel, the editor should behave/look differently
this could go far away of the simple "screen container" approach I've understood from the beginning - it would require to spread the consequences of such "if" all over the code.

But what I still fail to understand is: we already have two specific modules - one is meant for kogito (and with it I mean client-side only - maybe this is my misunderstanding) and the other for business central. What other differentiation could possible be? If we are saying that some behavior of an editor inside VSCode must be different from the github extension, then we are saying that potentially for every new possible channel a different implementation should be provided, and that would lead to nightmare too, IMHO.
I think that editors should be thought as composable pieces - with the wrapper layer provided only to allow the client-side requirements. Beside that, they should be absolutely agnostic about the container they are running in.

Hi @gitgabrio IDK the full purpose of channel other than what I've said above that some editors in some channels may need to behave differently - and I don't mean offer different feature sets.. We have 2 wrappers. Plain and simple. One for (current) Business Central and one for kogito (be it VSCode, GitHub etc). The feature sets in each wrapper remain constant however I've heard mention of, for example (and I may be mis-quoting), the Properties Panel (in DMN and BPMN) may be required to be open by default in VSCode but not GitHub.
If channel is meant to be providing the meta-data for something else perhaps @jesuino or someone in foundation can explain it's exact purpose.
updated PR with commit c6760d6
KogitoChannel is an enum. Not sure an empty optional can be returned as we state in javadoc.
